utterances: But when Semmerling started digging into allegations that Wisconsin had been cooking the books to get federal grant money, her own troubles began.
It was pretty awful.
I had - you know, you didn't know where to turn.
Here's the issue.
A federal law called the Juvenile Justice Delinquency and Prevention Act allocates grant money to states.
In return, states are supposed to protect young offenders and make sure they're not housed with adult criminals.

But Semmerling had a source who told her Wisconsin had been doing just that - putting kids who were abused in foster care and who ran away in jails next to adult criminals and still collecting federal grant money designed to protect those kids.
She became a bloodhound trying to find out who was responsible for mixing domestic violence victims with hardened criminals - and to stopping it.
So far they have not seemed to have anything like the strength they've had in the past.
Some of the people who were funding them in the past have stepped back, T.
Boone Pickens, the Texas oil man, among others.
They don't seem to be quite as interested in putting this forward as they have been in the past.
Now that could change.
It could change overnight.
It may be changing even as we speak.
And at some point or another, we would expect that there will be independent expenditures in favor of both candidates.
And certainly, John McCain is counting on that because he's taking public funds.
He'll only have 85 million dollars to a much larger amount of money Barack Obama will have to spend.
You know, that came out last week, that news that he's not taking public funds.
Has he suffered for it politically?
Some ad he will, but it's probably not going to be a game changer.
It will certainly be a blot on his image as a transformative figure, a new guy, somebody who's not just same old, same old.
And the reformers, some of them, will be mad.

Some of them will go to McCain, but bottom line, you know, if Barack Obama can raise 300 million dollars and more primarily in small contributions, you know, he can put half a dozen states in play that would not be in play otherwise.
He can be on the air.
He can organize on the ground.
And with McCain stuck at 85 million, well, why would Obama want to spike the biggest gun anyone's ever brought to a fight like this?
NPR senior Washington editor Ron Elving.
Thanks as always.
Thank you, Madeleine.
From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Coming up, why Hillary Clinton is trying to shame Barack Obama.
We get our political analysis fix from NPR's Ron Elving.
Senator Clinton is looking for a win in Texas next week.
To do that she'll need to hold onto a constituency she has traditionally considered hers.
And that is Latinos.
Texas has the third largest Latino population in the country.
Producer Martina Castro has been traveling around Texas.
She talked with some Latino Democrats in Irving, Austin and Belton.
Oh, my god.
It's a dream coming to see President Clinton and support Hillary.
I'm from Belton, Texas.
I work in a financial institution.
And I am 54 years of age, and my name is Carrie Ortiz.
I like Obama.
I don't have anything against him.
I think he's still a young person, a young candidate, and a great senator.
I think he has his own goals.
And I think maybe give him another four years and he'll be ready.
Okay.
My name is Ramon Garcia.
I'm from Mexico and my age is 29 years old and I'm a plumber.
And who do you support?
Hillary Clinton.
What are the issues in general that are important to you in the race.
There are three issues.
The first one is the war of Iraq.
I didn't see any benefits for us to be over there spending all the money.
The second one is the deficit that we have at this moment.
And the third one is immigration.
Yeah.
My name is Erica Gonzales.
I'm 28 years old, and I'm originally from Eagle Pass, Texas, the border of Texas and Mexico.
Right now I'm supporting Barack Obama.
I know that I was very hopeful when I first heard that a person of color was running for president.
Really I just don't want another Clinton in the office.
I just don't.
I really don't.
And to me, Barack has shown some hope.
I mean, I feel that there's hope there.
Okay.
Sabino Santaria.
I'm from Austin, Texas.
And I was born here and never left.
I always loved the young people, so I went with Obama.
Like every other generation, we need somebody new and fresh.
Like in my generation we were behind Bill Clinton all the way from the beginning and we wanted that type of energy.
And that's the way I see Obama.
He has the energy.
A few Latino voters in Texas.
Recent polls show Barack Obama is now leading among Latino voters in Texas.
I spoke earlier with Lydia Camarillo.
She's the vice president of the Southwest Voter Registration Education Project in San Antonio.
And I asked her why Senator Obama has pulled ahead of Senator Clinton.
The two issues I think that are the defining and distinctive issues that are important to the Latino electorate is the bringing back the troops home and then, of course, the immigration question.
The minute that he moved forward the idea that driver's licenses would be provided to immigrants in California he received 29 percent of the electorate in California that was Latino because of that.

It's interesting that you mention the driver's license issue for illegal immigrants as a key, at least symbolic, issue for a lot of Latinos, because earlier on in this campaign Senator Clinton did initially support driver's licenses for illegal immigrants.
And then she changed her mind.
You're saying that that actually was probably not a good strategic move for her in terms of courting the Latino vote.
That's correct.
That's what I'm saying.
The Clinton campaign has always assumed and functioned from the very beginning, before the primaries, that she was the presumptive nominee of the Democratic Party.
They strategically decided that it was important to go after the swing vote or the vote that they were going to capture and take in the general election.
And they did not focus on maintaining what is considered their base vote.
Before it all started they believed that the African American vote, as well as the Latino vote, along with the women vote, was their base vote.
The immigration question becomes the litmus test for our community as to how those who will be governing us how they will act once they are in office.
We're talking about the Latino electorate, the Latino vote, as if it were a monolithic vote, but is it?
It's not, but it is.
There are some similarities.
The Latino electorate understands that education is a ticket to progress or out of poverty.
The Latino electorate is concerned with jobs in the economy, which are issues that everybody's thinking of.
Both candidates have similar responses to issues that matter, as does the Democrat Party.
Semmerling uncovered leads that the practice wasn't isolated to Wisconsin, but her bosses allegedly told her not to go there.
Eventually, she says, the Justice Department yanked her from the case altogether.
I ended up with an autoimmune disease which I really did not know that I had, but the stress that I endured exacerbated it.
She ended up taking medical retirement, but Semmerling refused to give up, and she reached out to the federal office that supports whistleblowers again and again.
Her lawyer, Tom Devine.
The Office of Special Counsel found a substantial likelihood she was right about all those charges, and they've ordered the attorney general to conduct an independent investigation.
A Justice Department spokesman says it's committed to ensuring young people are protected from harm inside corrections facilities.
Meanwhile, someone else is investigating the issue, too.
I see it this way - oversight, oversight, oversight.
That's Iowa Republican Senator Charles Grassley, the new chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

The fact that the Justice Department is not overseeing how juveniles are treated in those instances and they're still getting the federal dollars - then it's the federal administrators that are at fault.
And we obviously want to correct that.
Grassley has made juvenile justice one of his top priorities this year.
He sent a letter to Justice this month demanding information about possible fraud in the grant program not just in Wisconsin, but four other states.
And he's introduced a bipartisan bill that would reauthorize the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act.
His legislation includes tougher standards to make sure juveniles are not detained with adults behind bars.
For her part, Jill Semmerling says it's a relief someone is finally listening.
She says she hopes states and the federal government will become better stewards of taxpayer money and better protectors of vulnerable young people.
Carrie Johnson, NPR News, Washington.
We'll report next on a place in Pakistan where no law prevails, and even young women can be killed with impunity.
Earlier this month, a 25-year-old woman was gunned down in the street.
She was living near the city of Peshawar, close to the border with Afghanistan.
She ran an organization that provides information for women about their rights.
So far, nobody has been arrested for her killing, and in all likelihood, nobody will be.
NPR's Mike Shuster has the story from Islamabad.
Her name is Farida Afridi.
It was on July 4th, early in the morning.
She was leaving her home to go to her office in Peshawar.
What happened next has shocked the local community, says Zar Ali Khan, who heads a consortium of activist groups in Peshawar.
When she was coming from her home early in the morning at 6 a.m., she was intercepted by two motorcyclists.
The men on the motorcycles pulled out guns.
This was something that Farida Afridi had been warned about many times, says Ali Khan.
Three years ago, she created SAWERA, or the Society for the Empowerment of Women in Rural Areas.
She gave lectures, provided information on women's rights.
And in the process, she caught the attention of some in northwest Pakistan who didn't like it.
They had warned her not to go and work for the empowerment of women, for the rights of women.
At least a dozen warnings, says Ali Khan.
Then came the attack.
The men on the motorcycles opened fire.
Farida was hit five times in the head and chest.
And she died instantly, on the spot.
The motorcyclists sped off.
So far, no one has claimed responsibility for the killing, but when Ali Khan sat in mourning with Farida's father, he said he asked him who he thought had carried out the murder.
I put the question: Who killed her?
He said you know, and I know well.
Our enemies are around us.
Farida's family and their larger tribe believe militants with links to both al-Qaida and the Pakistani Taliban were responsible.
Farida's group worked for the empowerment of women in the tribal areas of northwest Pakistan.
But just what does that mean?
It's a question I put to Farzana Bari, a professor of gender studies at Quaid-i-Azam University in Islamabad.
Essentially, we are asking about the women having fundamental access to resource.
That means education, good health, ability to work, economically independent, and make choices for themselves, you know, for their own lives, you know.
